awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2019 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Michael Lindsey is "Applied analysis for quantum chemistry and condensed matter physics." The host institution for the fellowship is New York University Courant Institute, and the sponsoring scientist is Robert Kohn.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The focus of this project was the development of computational methods for quantum many-body systems. A noteworthy example task is the electronic structure problem, the problem of determining the state of the electrons in a system with fixed atomic nuclei. Since direct numerical solution of the many-body Schrodinger equation is intractable even for systems of moderate size, there is a diverse hierarchy of approximate methods, trading off to varying degrees between accuracy and computational efficiency. Computational methods for quantum many-body systems are relied upon in countless scientific and technological pursuits, both in academia and in industry, ranging from the study of biomolecular systems, to the design of new materials, to the study of physical phenomena like high-temperature superconductivity.

The project has advanced several frameworks of computation for quantum problems. One such framework is given by quantum embedding theories, which view a large system as being composed of smaller fragments that are treated with high accuracy and embedded in the larger system in a mutually consistent way. This project introduced a new quantum embedding theory that furnishes guaranteed lower bounds on the ground-state energy, as well as fast algorithms for solving problems within this theory. The project also advanced algorithms for and mathematical understanding of a widely-used existing quantum embedding theory called density matrix embedding theory (DMET).

Another framework for quantum problems is given by Monte Carlo methods, which rely on randomization as a key resource. In particular, variational Monte Carlo (VMC) uses Monte Carlo sampling to optmize a quantum wavefunction within a parametric class of wavefunctions, specified, for example, by a neural network ansatz. This project has advanced a new optimization approach for VMC which was applied to the optimization of such neural quantum states.

Other quantum Monte Carlo methods are based on exact reformulation of the quantum many-body problem in terms of a path integral. We introduced new algorithms for sampling such path integral formulations, which we used to study quantum phase transitions that are motivated by high-temperature superconductivity.

The results of this project have impacts on other disciplines beyond the study of quantum systems. Specifically, we have developed general-purpose Markov chain Monte Carlo tools, extended tensor network methods to solve high-dimensional partial differential equations, and introduced marginal-based relaxations of difficult optimization problems. These innovations offer powerful new ways to tackle complex probabilistic models and optimization problems across a range of scientific and engineering fields, including statistics, machine learning, and statistical mechanics.
